description: From Middle English seewater, se water, from Old English sǣwæter (“seawater”), equivalent to sea +‎ water. Cognate with Saterland Frisian Seewoater (“seawater”), West Frisian seewetter (“seawater”), Dutch zeewater (“seawater”), Icelandic sjóvatn (“seawater”).

examples: The continual seawater splashes corroded our equipment

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Associated in some way with seawater, or intended for dealing with seawater.
examples: The sharks in the aquarium had to be kept in a seawater tank
Aboard the ship we needed seawater soap for washing our clothes
Though it was a nuisance to arrange them, we found the seawater showers very refreshing

entries.meaning: The saltwater of a sea or ocean.
